citation.article-title: Rhodospira trueperi gen. nov., spec. nov., a new phototrophic Proteobacterium of the alpha group

p.s: Description of Rhodospira trueperi sp. nov.
Rhodospira trueperi (true.pe.ri M.L. gen.n., named for Hans Georg Trüper, a German microbiologist, who contributed significantly to our knowledge of the anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria)
Cells vibrioid- to spirilloid-shaped, 0.6–0.8 μm wide, 1.5–3.0 μm long.
Motile by bipolar tufts of flagella (two to five fibrils).
Intracytoplasmic membrane system of vesicular type.
Anaerobically grown cultures are beige to peach-colored.
Living cell suspensions show absorption maxima at 397, 458, 490, 600, 689, 801, 889, and 986 nm.
Major photosynthetic pigments are the carotenoid tetrahydrospirilloxanthin and bacteriochlorophyll b.
Photoorganotrophic under anoxic conditions: organic substrates utilized are acetate, pyruvate, propionate, butyrate, valerate, lactate, fumarate, malate, succinate, and crotonate.
It is oxidized to elemental sulfur, which cannot be oxidized further to sulfate.
Biotin, thiamine, and pantothenate are required as growth factors.
Optimal growth is at 25–30° C, pH 7.3–7.5, and at 2% NaCl.
Growth ranges are 0.5–5% NaCl, pH 7.0–7.8, and 20–35°C.
The nucleotide sequence of the 16S rRNA of the type strain is most similar to that of Rhodospirillum rubrum, with a similarity value of 92.8%.
The mol% G+C of the DNA is 65.7.
Habitat: peach-colored layer of a laminated microbial mat of Great Sippewissett Salt Marsh, Mass., USA.
